H0.text: The deserts receive the most direct sunlight on Earth.

H1.text: The South Pole is the location on Earth that receives the most direct sunlight.

H2.text: The equator receives the most direct sunlight on Earth.

H3.text: The Western Hemisphere is the location on Earth that receives the most direct sunlight.

A4.text: On and near the equator (on Earth), noontime sunlight appears almost directly overhead (no more than about 23Â° from the zenith) every day, year-round.

A5.text: On the equinoxes (approximately 20 March and 23 September) the subsolar point crosses Earth's equator at a shallow angle, sunlight shines perpendicular to Earth's axis of rotation, and all latitudes have nearly a 12-hour day and 12-hour night.
